--- John Arrowwood <jarrowwx@...> wrote:
> Excellent, thank you!

No problem. :)

> A question...do I need to normalize my data?  Do I
> have to specify integer 
> coordinates that correspond to pixels?  Or can I
> just put real numbers in 
> for coordinates and specify a viewport that
> encompasses the whole thing?

There are no pixels in SVG...its a vector graphic
format.  Otherwise, I'm not sure I understand your
questions.

Basically, though, if you're interested in using SVG
as a graphical layout tool (and even though I'm an
advocate of its use for dynamic graphical generation
and cross-platform utility, it is by no means the best
or only way to graphically represent data), then you
don't want to be coding it by hand.

The power of SVG comes from leveraging data stored in
XML format.

You have part of a document stored like this:

<neuron id="16" type="in" hint-layer="2"
hint-position="3" />

Then you use an XSL style sheet, which might have a
code like this:

<xsl:for-each select="neuron">
   <xsl:variable name="neuron_position">
      <xsl:value-of select="position()" />
   </xsl:variable>
   <circle cx="{75*$layer_number}"
cy="{50*$neuron_position}" r="10" fill="blue"
stroke="black" stroke-width="1" />
</xsl:for-each>

Which then generates the viewable SVG file.

I got the idea from the Adobe SVG Demo site.  This
demo showed molecular diagrams generated from CML
(Chemical Markup Language), an XML standard for
chemists:

http://www.adobe.com/svg/demos/devtrack/chemical.html

If you're interested in learning how to use SVG, you
probably want to start by deciding upon a good XML
format for the data you want to represent and
graphically display.  The Adobe website is a good
place to start, and there are also plenty of good
references on the net.  I'm happy to answer any
questions as well.

Derek
